Debenhams and Peacocks among 360 firms named and shamed for failing to pay minimum wage The big brands have been rapped for flouting the legal pay floor and not giving workers their rightful rates Share Comments By Ben Glaze 19:00, 15 FEB 2017 Updated 19:05, 15 FEB 2017 News Thousands of workers have been denied what they were owed (Photo: Getty) Share Comments Get politics updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email Hundreds of firms which cheated workers out of the minimum wage are named and shamed tonight.
Top brands including Debenhams and Peacocks were among companies ripping off employees, according to Business Department figures.
In total, more than 15,500 staff were duped out of almost a million pounds by 360 employers.
Business Minister Margot James said: “Every worker in the UK is entitled to at least the national minimum or living wage and this government will ensure they get it.
Margot James named and shamed the firms involved (Photo: handout) Full list of 360 employers named and shamed for failing to pay minimum wage
“That is why we have named and shamed more than 350 employers who failed to pay the legal minimum , sending the clear message to employers that minimum wage abuses will not go unpunished.”
The 360 firms identified underpaid 15,520 workers a total of £995,233.
They included hotels, restaurants and nurseries.
HM Revenue and Customs slapped guilty firms with £800,000 of fines, as well as recouping the owed cash for employees.
The biggest offender identified in the latest list of shame was high street giant Debenhams, which failed to pay £134,894.83 to 11,858 workers - an average of £11.37 each.
The chain, whose chief executive Sergio Bucher was appointed last year on a bumper £3.8million pay package, blamed a “technical error” for denying staff their hard-earned cash.
A spokesman said: “ Debenhams made a technical error in its payroll calculations, which resulted in an average underpayment of around £10 per person to the affected colleagues in 2015.
Debenhams blamed a technical error for denying employees an average of £11.37 each (Photo: Getty) MARGOT JAMES: We're not afraid to take on disgraceful employers who fail to pay up
“As a responsible employer Debenhams is committed to the national minimum wage, and as soon as the error was identified by a routine HMRC audit last year, we reimbursed all those affected.
“We have apologised to all our colleagues affected and have taken steps to ensure it cannot happen again.”
Peacock Stores failed to pay £2,256.58 to 42 workers.
The chain is part of the Edinburgh Woollen Mill group which is owned by billionaire Philip Day, worth £1.05billion, according to the Sunday Times Rich List.
Posh London eatery Osteria San Lorenzo, part of the world famous San Lorezno group of restaurants, underpaid 29 workers by a total of £53,496.57 - a staggering £1,844 each.
Pembrokeshire Care Ltd in west Wales duped 154 workers out of £55,056.75 - an average of £357.51 per employee.
(Photo: PA) Fallowfield Country House Hotel in Oxfordshire underpaid six staff by £19,436.88 - nearly £3,240 each.
At Harley Street practice Tasman Ltd, one worker lost out on a whopping £11,799.
Six staff at Drivecheck Ltd in Hull missed out on a total of £24,363.36 - an average of £4,060 each.
Two employees at Glover’s Bakery in Preston were denied a total of £11,320.33 - an average of £5,660 per worker.
(Photo: Getty) Age Concern in Newcastle-upon-Tyne failed to pay one worker £1,737.32, Scottish football club St Mirren denied an employee £1,277 and the 118 directory inquiries firm failed to pay an employee £422.
Workers aged 25 and over should be paid at least £7.20 an hour under minimum wage laws, which the Government rebranded the “national living wage” last year.
TUC General Secretary Frances O’Grady said: “This should be a wake-up call for employers who value their reputation.
"If you cheat your staff out of the minimum wage you will be named and shamed.
Frances O'Grady urged firms to pay workers the rightful rate (Photo: Daily Mirror) “But we also need to see prosecutions and higher fines for the most serious offenders, especially those who deliberately flout the law.
“Minimum wage dodgers must have nowhere to hide. We need to see strong unions in every workplace to stop these abuses from happening.”
